Subject: Question Re: HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=VnixjNC-Dgp10kzwOVIcnkjUAUAmiyrAdmA8dqDBJCaRRsCp7wWE

Andy,

There are still a lot of ways to configure the substrate for such a =

problem, so it's difficult to give a general answer.  For example, 
you mi=
ght have a single 2D input layer connecting to a single output 
node (yes/n=
o); or you could have a multilayer 3D input field (where 
each 2D layer is =
a type of object) connecting to a 2D output field 
(where each pixel answer=
s the question, is there overlap here?).  
You might have a hidden layer, a=
nd you might not.  You might allow 
the hidden layer to express lateral con=
nections, and you might not.  
You might have a 3D hidden layer or a 2D hid=
den layer.  You might 
embed everything in 3D, or you might map a 3D coordi=
nate to a 2D, or 
a 2D or a 3D, etc..

In each case, the implications are d=
ifferent about how proximities 
are incorporated or expressed.  In some cas=
es it can be explicit 
within parts of the substrate; in some cases it is i=
mplicit.  For 
example, if there is only a single output node and a 2D shee=
t of 
inputs, then the CPPN does not even need to take a target location 
a=
s input, since there is only one target.  In that case you just 
query for =
each input node what weight is coming out of it.  In such 
a case, it is tr=
ue that you do not explicitly provide a proximity 
input to the CPPN; howev=
er proximity is still implicit within the 
representation since input nodes=
 that are near each other are also 
nearby in the function domain of the CP=
PN, that is, it can use that 
nearness even though it is not explicitly pro=
vided as input.  

Please let me know if I didn't answer adequately and I c=
an try to be 
more specific, but I might need more detail on the precise sc=
enario 
you are considering.

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" =
<a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> Ken,
> 
>    One troubling "detail" is that of diff=
erences in dimensionality 
> between substrate inputs and outputs. In the e=
xamples used in the 
> various papers, the dimensionality of the substrate =
input and 
output 
> nodes, as applied to the Hypercube inputs, were identi=
cal (i.e. 
x_in, 
> y_in, x_out, y_out). This simplifies the concept of dis=
tance. But 
the 
> problem could just as easily have been: Do the two squar=
es on the 
> visual field overlap? (yes/no). In this case, dimensionality o=
f 
the 
> substrate input and output nodes, as applied to the Hypercube 
in=
puts, 
> have differing dimensionality, even though the answer is strongly =

> dependent on proximity in the input visual field. Any experience 
or 
> =
comments on this seemly more common general condition?
> 
> Thanks,
>    An=
dy Carl 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wr=
ote:
> >
> > Andy, I'd say this is a about right.  I elaborate a bit below =

each 
> > part of your question:
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "af=
carl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Jason or Ken,
> > > 
> > >    I am atte=
mpting to understand the nature of inputs & 
outputs 
> as 
> > > applied t=
o both the Hypercube and substrate networks, without 
> being 
> > > limite=
d to the geometric nature of the visual-based examples. 
The 
> > > example=
s provided were helpful, but I am striving for a more 
> > general 
> > > g=
uideline for application to more general problems.
> > > 
> > >    Would it=
 be correct to say that:
> > > 
> > > (a) Substrate Network: Inputs & Outpu=
ts identified as typical 
to 
> > > application of conventional NEAT to a p=
roblem of interest;
> > > 
> > 
> > This statement is correct although you =
might do things that you 
> would 
> > avoid doing in conventional NEAT bec=
ause HyperNEAT can deal with 
so 
> > many more inputs and outputs.  So you=
 might for example output a 
> high 
> > resolution representation of your =
possible decisions, which is 
> > something you normally wouldn't do in reg=
ular NEAT.
> > 
> > > (b) Hypercube Network: (i) Inputs: Other 
descriptors=
/parameters 
> > (i.e. 
> > > geometric coordinates being a subset thereof)=
, associated with 
a 
> > given 
> > > substrate network node (i.e. like a =
timestamp associated with 
a 
> > > coordinate point comprising a trajector=
y), mutually exclusive 
of 
> > the 
> > > descriptor/parameter expressly i=
dentified in the substrate 
node, 
> > each 
> > > being collected together=
 and collectively identified as either 
> > a "from" 
> > > or "to" termina=
tor of a link between any two substrate nodes; 
and 
> > (ii) 
> > > Output=
: Weight of link between the currently identified "from" 
> > and "to" 
> >=
 > substrate nodes.
> > > 
> > 
> > I think this characterizes it well, alt=
hough there is even more 
> > flexibility.  You can for example use additio=
nal outputs on the 
> CPPN 
> > to represent additional attributes of links=
 and/or nodes.  
> > 
> > The timestamp idea is interesting- if I understan=
d correctly it 
> would 
> > cause the network to change over time in a det=
erministic way.  
> > Although maybe I'm misunderstanding.  But certainly t=
hings like 
> that 
> > are possible.  
> > 
> > It's difficult to write an=
 accurate general description of 
exactly 
> > what goes in and comes out o=
f the CPPN at this point because I 
have 
> > no doubt that at this early s=
tage that new ideas are going to 
> broaden 
> > the possibilities beyond w=
hat I am currently aware of.   But 
what 
> you 
> > said captures it prett=
y well for now.

> > ken
